search_result.title: Christina district first in Delaware to announce 2021-22 mask policy
search_result.text:
Gov. John Carney is looking at the potential use of emergency powers to issue a universal mask mandate in Delaware schools, but did not say for sure at a press conference Thursday whether or not it will happen.

He did say, however, that the state will "need to make a decision pretty quickly" as the 2021-22 school year approaches.

While districts await Carney's potential order, one of Delaware's largest public school districts will require masks for all students and staff, regardless of their vaccination status.

The Christina School District board announced during a Tuesday meeting that it would be following guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to begin the 2021-22 school year.

Christina, which had one of the earliest board meetings in August, is the first public district to announce plans for the upcoming school year.

Other districts either haven't yet announced plans or have board meetings scheduled for next week or the week after – when plans are likely to be announced and discussed.

Those meetings and decisions, however, could come after Carney issues an order. Delaware's emergency order ended Tuesday, July 13. The expiration of that order freed school districts to make their own decisions on policies like face coverings.

While further guidance is coming prior to the school year, Red Clay – Delaware's largest district – was requiring students in summer programs to wear masks as of last week.

"We are monitoring CDC and state guidance on the issue and will provide our guidance prior to the start of the new school year," a spokesperson said.

During the Tuesday night meeting, Christina Superintendent Dan Shelton said the district did not run into many problems with masks among students and that "adults" were responsible for making it an issue.

He also acknowledged that the science and recommendations have not been consistent and that policies for the district could change "on a day-by-day, hour-by-hour basis."

Christina schools will be open for in-person learning to start the 2021-22 school year, and Carney and Dr. Karyl Rattay, the director of the Division of Public Health, reiterated the desire for all schools to be open in 2021-22.

"We can’t afford another year (like 2020)," Carney said.

The Christina district, said board member Claire O'Neal, has committed to following the recommended guidance since the pandemic began.

Public comment Tuesday night did not include a debate over masking.

But the mask vs. no mask conversation has dominated headlines and school board meetings almost nationwide in recent months.

BUS DRIVER SHORTAGE: School officials are trying everything to fight bus driver shortage, even paying parents

During a Milford school board meeting Monday night, for example, four people spoke during public comment – all with concerns about masking. Three people spoke out against masks and one person in favor.

One who spoke against masking called the face coverings a "political tool."

"I think any reasonable person who looks at the science and sees past the politics would come to the conclusion that our kids are not at danger," said a man who said he had three elementary-aged children.

He asked the Milford board to see past the politicization and to not require masks.

A woman with a child under 12 said she was comfortable "yielding to people in this world who have done their research" in medical school "and haven’t done their research on Facebook and YouTube."

"Children under 12, like my daughter, are not yet eligible to be vaccinated," she said. "The mask is protecting her. As a member of a society, we have a responsibility to each other that goes beyond our own desire."

The burden, the mother said, should be on the state to make a decision and not left to the Milford board.

ZONING LINES: One community in Magnolia makes its plea to the Caesar Rodney School District over an imaginary line

Another woman said parents should get to decide whether their child wears a mask or doesn't.

Board members in Milford did not respond to any debates over masking, as it was not on the meeting agenda.

"We saw very little spread in our schools last year," Rattay said. "Masks work."

The CDC reversed course in late July, announcing recommendations that all grade school students, teachers and staff be masked, regardless of their vaccination status, during the 2021-22 school year as worry over the delta variant heightened.

That came less than three weeks after the agency announced that vaccinated teachers and students wouldn't need to wear masks inside school buildings this fall, and two months after the agency lifted mask requirements in most public settings for vaccinated people.

Delaware in late May adopted the CDC's guidance that at the time removed all social distancing restrictions and made masks optional for everyone – vaccinated and unvaccinated.

Carney stopped doing weekly virus-related press conferences but held one Thursday morning as the delta variant has resulted in a rapid increase in cases and hospitalizations over the last six weeks.

Carney did not announce any new mandates or sweeping changes Thursday other than alluding to the potential for statewide school mask mandates.

There had previously been competing advice from the CDC and the American Academy of Pediatrics, adding to the uncertainty for schools.

Both institutions expressed the need for schools to fully reopen, but the Academy of Pediatrics, in guidance issued after the July 9 CDC recommendations, said those in schools should be masked.

Restrictions and safety measures have varied across state and county lines. In California, for example, the state health department still requires masks indoors in K-12 schools when children are present, regardless of vaccination status.

In neighboring Arizona, lawmakers banned school districts from instituting mask mandates. Similar laws were passed in Iowa and Texas.

Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, who has been critical of COVID-19 restrictions, signed an executive order making face masks optional across the state in schools and leaving it up to parents.

As of Thursday, 44% of people aged 12 to 17 in Delaware have been vaccinated. That percentage represents the lowest share among all age groups in the state, according to the state's online vaccine tracker – though only 45.7% of people aged 18 to 34 have been vaccinated.

Officials anticipate at least the Pfizer vaccine could be approved for children younger than 12 in September or October.

Delaware officials last month announced a $15 million partnership between the state's health and education departments and a California-based company to bring rapid antigen coronavirus tests to schools around the state in an effort to "prevent transmission and keep schools open," the health department said in July.

The tests will be free to students and staff. Parents and guardians will have to give permission for children to be tested.

"I know that there's a lot of individuals who think, 'Well, kids are not at risk; kids aren't, you know, going to have a lot of problems from this.' But first of all, for probably the first half of this pandemic, most kids weren't in school and then when kids were in the school setting, they were all wearing masks and they were socially distanced and we saw very little spread," Rattay said.

"If they all wear masks, then we'll be able to limit spread, but it's hard to get all kids back and keep them as far apart as 6 feet and so there is going to be some level of risk especially for unvaccinated individuals.

"To be able to test on a regular basis is going to help prevent the in-school spread."

Contact reporter Jeff Neiburg at jneiburg@delawareonline.com. Follow him on Twitter @Jeff_Neiburg.

Jea Street sifted through decades of memory — preparing Black families for desegregation, fighting school closures, pushing for equitable funding inside Wilmington city limits — as he listened to some of the same discussion he’s heard for 20 years.

Back in the late 1970s, the grizzled community advocate watched his school district get chopped into four new pieces under court order. He watched bus routes retrace, only to dramatically change all together. He watched Delaware demand and seemingly unravel the very progress of school desegregation in its largest city.
